title: Kepler's laws of planetary motion
text:
In <a href="astronomy">astronomy</a>, Kepler's laws of planetary motion, published by <a href="Johannes%20Kepler">Johannes Kepler</a> between 1609 and 1619, describe the orbits of <a href="planet">planet</a>s around the <a href="Sun">Sun</a>. The laws modified the <a href="Copernican%20heliocentrism">heliocentric theory</a> of <a href="Nicolaus%20Copernicus">Nicolaus Copernicus</a>, replacing its circular <a href="orbit">orbit</a>s and <a href="epicycles">epicycles</a> with elliptical trajectories, and explaining how planetary velocities vary. The three laws state that:
The elliptical orbits of planets were indicated by calculations of the orbit of <a href="Mars">Mars</a>. From this, Kepler inferred that other bodies in the <a href="Solar%20System">Solar System</a>, including those farther away from the Sun, also have elliptical orbits. The second law helps to establish that when a planet is closer to the Sun, it travels faster. The third law expresses that the farther a planet is from the Sun, the slower its orbital speed, and vice versa.
<a href="Isaac%20Newton">Isaac Newton</a> showed in 1687 that relationships like Kepler's would apply in the Solar System as a consequence of his own <a href="Newton%27s%20laws%20of%20motion">laws of motion</a> and <a href="Newton%27s%20law%20of%20universal%20gravitation">law of universal gravitation</a>.
Comparison to Copernicus.
<a href="Johannes%20Kepler">Johannes Kepler</a>'s laws improved the model of <a href="Copernicus">Copernicus</a>. If the <a href="Orbital%20eccentricity">eccentricities</a> of the planetary <a href="orbit">orbit</a>s are taken as zero, then Kepler basically agreed with Copernicus:
The eccentricities of the orbits of those planets known to Copernicus and Kepler are small, so the foregoing rules give fair approximations of planetary motion, but Kepler's laws fit the observations better than does the model proposed by Copernicus. Kepler's corrections are:
The <a href="Orbital%20eccentricity">eccentricity</a> of the <a href="orbit%20of%20the%20Earth">orbit of the Earth</a> makes the time from the <a href="March%20equinox">March equinox</a> to the <a href="September%20equinox">September equinox</a>, around 186 days, unequal to the time from the September equinox to the March equinox, around 179 days. A diameter would cut the orbit into equal parts, but the plane through the Sun parallel to the <a href="equator">equator</a> of the Earth cuts the orbit into two parts with areas in a 186 to 179 ratio, so the eccentricity of the orbit of the Earth is approximately
which is close to the correct value (0.016710218). The accuracy of this calculation requires that the two dates chosen be along the elliptical orbit's minor axis and that the midpoints of each half be along the major axis. As the two dates chosen here are equinoxes, this will be correct when <a href="perihelion">perihelion</a>, the date the Earth is closest to the Sun, falls on a <a href="solstice">solstice</a>. The current perihelion, near January 4, is fairly close to the solstice of December 21 or 22.
Nomenclature.
It took nearly two centuries for current formulation of Kepler's work to take on its settled form. <a href="Voltaire">Voltaire</a>'s "Eléments de la philosophie de Newton" ("Elements of Newton's Philosophy") of 1738 was the first publication to use the terminology of "laws". The "<a href="Biographical%20Encyclopedia%20of%20Astronomers">Biographical Encyclopedia of Astronomers</a>" in its article on Kepler (p. 620) states that the terminology of scientific laws for these discoveries was current at least from the time of <a href="Joseph%20de%20Lalande">Joseph de Lalande</a>. It was the exposition of <a href="Robert%20Small%20%28minister%29">Robert Small</a>, in "An account of the astronomical discoveries of Kepler" (1814) that made up the set of three laws, by adding in the third. Small also claimed, against the history, that these were <a href="empirical%20law">empirical law</a>s, based on <a href="inductive%20reasoning">inductive reasoning</a>.
Further, the current usage of "Kepler's Second Law" is something of a misnomer. Kepler had two versions, related in a qualitative sense: the "distance law" and the "area law". The "area law" is what became the Second Law in the set of three; but Kepler did himself not privilege it in that way.
History.
Kepler published his first two laws about planetary motion in 1609, having found them by analyzing the astronomical observations of <a href="Tycho%20Brahe">Tycho Brahe</a>. Kepler's third law was published in 1619. Kepler had believed in the <a href="Copernican%20heliocentrism">Copernican model</a> of the Solar System, which called for circular orbits, but he could not reconcile Brahe's highly precise observations with a circular fit to Mars' orbit – Mars coincidentally having the highest <a href="Orbital%20eccentricity">eccentricity</a> of all planets except Mercury. His first law reflected this discovery.
In 1621, Kepler noted that his third law applies to the <a href="Galilean%20moons">four brightest moons</a> of <a href="Jupiter">Jupiter</a>. <a href="Godefroy%20Wendelin">Godefroy Wendelin</a> also made this observation in 1643. The second law, in the "area law" form, was contested by <a href="Nicolaus%20Mercator">Nicolaus Mercator</a> in a book from 1664, but by 1670 his "<a href="Philosophical%20Transactions">Philosophical Transactions</a>" were in its favour. As the century proceeded it became more widely accepted. The reception in Germany changed noticeably between 1688, the year in which Newton's "<a href="Philosophi%C3%A6%20Naturalis%20Principia%20Mathematica">Principia</a>" was published and was taken to be basically Copernican, and 1690, by which time work of <a href="Gottfried%20Leibniz">Gottfried Leibniz</a> on Kepler had been published.
Newton was credited with understanding that the second law is not special to the inverse square law of gravitation, being a consequence just of the radial nature of that law, whereas the other laws do depend on the inverse square form of the attraction. <a href="Carl%20Runge">Carl Runge</a> and <a href="Wilhelm%20Lenz">Wilhelm Lenz</a> much later identified a symmetry principle in the <a href="phase%20space">phase space</a> of planetary motion (the <a href="orthogonal%20group">orthogonal group</a> O(4) acting) which accounts for the first and third laws in the case of Newtonian gravitation, as <a href="conservation%20of%20angular%20momentum">conservation of angular momentum</a> does via rotational symmetry for the second law.

Third law.
The ratio of the square of an object's <a href="orbital%20period">orbital period</a> with the cube of the semi-major axis of its orbit is the same for all objects orbiting the same primary.
This captures the relationship between the distance of planets from the Sun, and their orbital periods.
Kepler enunciated in 1619 this third law in a laborious attempt to determine what he viewed as the "<a href="Musica%20universalis">music of the spheres</a>" according to precise laws, and express it in terms of musical notation. It was therefore known as the "harmonic law".

Planetary acceleration.
<a href="Isaac%20Newton">Isaac Newton</a> computed in his "<a href="Philosophi%C3%A6%20Naturalis%20Principia%20Mathematica">Philosophiæ Naturalis Principia Mathematica</a>" the <a href="acceleration">acceleration</a> of a planet moving according to Kepler's first and second law.
This implies that the Sun may be the physical cause of the acceleration of planets. However, Newton states in his "Principia" that he considers forces from a mathematical point of view, not a physical, thereby taking an instrumentalist view. Moreover, he does not assign a cause to gravity.
